did.abstract: Lottie Pozniak (Kaminski) was born in Hartford, Connecticut to the first generation of Polish Americans. She was very active in many Polish American cultural organizations. During World War II she participated in selling war bonds and organized many events to benefit troops. After the war she became a participant and promoter of Polish history and culture. She received many awards and recognitions for her work. The collection richly illustrates with printed and visual material Mrs. Pozniak's activities and the Polish American community in Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Lottie Pozniak (Kaminski) was born in Hartford, Connecticut to a family of Polish immigrants. She was a second generation Polish American, that came to maturity before the WWII. From her childhood Lottie was involved in Polish community, starting with her parent's involvement in the PNA and Polish National Home activities. Lottie dvoted her life to preserve and present Poland and Polish culture to her American friends. In her teenage years Lottie became very active in "Gwiazda" Dramatic Club, which promoted and fostered Polish tradition and culture through different dramatic works. Mrs. Pozniak studied advanced Polish history and language at Columbia University. She was involved in various organizations and spent hundred of hours on volunteer work, such as selling War bonds, entertaining troops, directing blood drives, and working with military personnel who had lost their sight in combat. After the war, Lottie Pozniak continued her involvement in various projects. She was still active in the Gwiazda club in addition to co-hosting radio programs and being a member of the Parish Ladies Guild of SS. Cyril and Methodious Church, Polish Women's Alliance, Polish National Alliance, Ladies Auxilliary of the Polish Legion of American Veterans, and PAC of Connecticut. Since the late 1960's Lottie has been involved in the Polish Cultural Club of Greater Hartford. She has romoted Polish culture by organizing and presenting artifacts and educational materials for various schools and libraries. She organized the Polish booth at the Connecticut Historical Society's ethnic day, Civic Center Food Fair, International Day at CCSU, and the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum in Hartford. For her active involvement she has received numerous recognitions and awards. Currently Lottie continues to promote her cultural heritage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of printed and visual material related to Polish history, culture, and cultural undertakings in Connecticut. Collection of photographs illustrates activities of Lottie Pozniak and organizations to which she belonged. Printed material consists of Mrs. Pozniak's documents related to Polish and Polish American issues and her active membership in various organizations.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.p: Most of the material in the collection was donated by Mrs. Lottie Pozniak in 1986. After that several donations were made with material collected after the first donation, in 1991, 1998, 2001 and 2003.
